status_message:
If you get news from Occupy Democrats, Resistance Report, Women's Rights News, or any number of other similar Facebook-based sites, know that they're not just "vampires," they're thieves. 

Sites like these often pilfer stories wholesale (including from Rewire), without attribution, to drive clicks and get ad revenue. In the process they sometimes tweak enough details that when you share the story, you're being unknowingly conscripted into the fake news business. What's more, they cut down on traffic to small, independent journalism outlets and help them make money off our work.
link_name: Vampire Webpages Suck Content From Legitimate Progressive News Sites

status_message:
Here's what's at stake in the case the Supreme Court is hearing this morning. It's not about birth control this time: it's about retirement benefits. But the arguments are going to rely heavily on the same logic that was used to deny birth control coverage for religious reasons.

Conservatives' assertions that institutions like Dignity Health, a Catholic hospital system and the country's fifth-largest health-care employer, fulfill some spiritual mission and should therefore be treated like a church are all smoke and bluster. These institutions want cover for ongoing attempts to nickel-and-dime their own workers and to discriminate, based on religious beliefs, when it comes to how and whom these institutions serve. And they're hoping the Roberts Court will give it to them.
link_name: The Supreme Court Could Give Religiously Affiliated Employers Even More Room to Discriminate - Rewire

status_message: The same names crop up again and again in defense of anti-choice pseudoscience; it's no coincidence. The gallery of "False Witnesses" who profit from peddling misinformation to legislatures, courts, and the media:  http://rewire.link/2nWUfDN

Some good news: Nevada just became the 36th state to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment, which passed Congress 45 years ago today but fell three states short of the minimum needed for ratification.

The amendment is simple: "Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex."

Why is this important now? Because an "originalist" (like Neil Gorsuch) would have to say that the Constitution doesn't protect women against sex discrimination. If Gorsuch is confirmed and lives up to his originalist billing, we should expect him to rule against women under the Constitution. But the ERA would give the Constitution a clear textual commitment to sex equality, something even the Court's most conservative justices couldn't deny.
link_name: A Small Ray of Light in Political News: Nevada's Ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment - Rewire

status_message:
According to Gorsuch's professional ethics course, women are grifters that employers should immediately view with suspicion. 

Jessica Mason Pieklo, Rewire's VP of Law and the Courts, relates her own experience:  "The suspicion that I faced as a young litigator—that my gender meant I wasn't fully committed to my career—wasn't subtle. The first full week of my job, the other female associates and a few of the junior partners decided to get together for a happy hour after work. As we were waiting in the law firm lobby for the elevator, the white, male hiring partner at our law firm snarked that it must be 'time for the sewing circle to meet,' seeming to suggest that we weren't so-called real lawyers." The structural bias didn't stop there, though.

status_message:
In 1995, Kelly Savage made plans to board a bus and, with her two young children, escape her abusive husband.

The day before she and her children got to the bus station, her husband beat her 3-and-a-half-year-old son, who died. Both were arrested. At her trial, the prosecutor argued that, because she had neither left her husband nor called the police, she was equally culpable for her son's death. Furthermore, the prosecutor characterized Savage as someone who manipulated the men in her life into repeatedly beating and raping her.

She is serving a life sentence without parole.
link_name: The Abuse Excuse: Dismissing Domestic Violence and Its Effects in the Criminal Court System - Rewire

status_message:
The day after Dr. George Tiller was murdered in 2009, the National Network of Abortion Funds received a $500 donation from Dr. Tiller himself, mailed in the week before he was shot in church. 

They used that donation—and many more that flooded in—to establish the George Tiller Memorial Fund, which helps people facing extreme barriers to abortion. Often the recipients have medical emergencies, or must travel across the country for care. A large percentage need later abortions. 

A new study examines the circumstances of the fund's recipients, bringing to woeful light the predicament of many in one of the world's wealthiest nations.
link_name: Study: Abortion Access is 'Desperate, Not Equal' - Rewire

status_message:
A favorite talking point for Republicans pushing to defund Planned Parenthood is that the services provided by the organization's affiliates throughout the country can be easily replaced by federally qualified health centers (FQHCs): community clinics.

However, it's been established that they cannot possibly absorb Planned Parenthood's patient load. What's more, many of them are religiously affiliated and refuse to prescribe birth control. 

Together, religiously-affiliated centers operate health clinics in dozens of locations throughout the nation and collected $38 million in Affordable Care Act (ACA) grants last year alone. 

Our investigation:
link_name: Those Health Centers the GOP Wants to Replace Planned Parenthood? Some Deny Contraception, Citing Religion - Rewire

status_message:
From 1919 to 1952, California coercively sterilized some 20,000 men and women, a disproportionate number of whom were of Mexican descent and often disabled or deemed "feeble-minded." But unlike other states such as North Carolina and Virginia, California has yet to offer any reparations for sterilization survivors as a step toward confronting this injustice.

Researchers who study the history of forced sterilization about what California should be doing for survivors of sterilization, many of whom are still here to tell there stories; and, critically, how we can prevent another wave of coerced procedures, both in California and in the rest of the United States.
link_name: 'When You Try to Stop It, Nothing Happens': A Q&A on the History of Coerced Sterilization in California - Rewire

status_message:
An abortion restriction in Arizona that runs counter to medical ethics would rob some parents of the opportunity to grieve after pregnancy loss. 

"Let the mother hold the baby and grieve," said Senate Minority Leader Katie Hobbs (D-Phoenix), who spoke of her own miscarriage. "When you know the infant will not survive, it is cruel and against medical ethics to administer that kind of resuscitative care that can actually harm the infant." 

The bill is opposed by the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and has drawn the opposition of the American Medical Association and other medical groups.
link_name: Arizona Lawmakers Pass 'Cruel' Anti-Choice Law - Rewire

status_message:
Today is #DayOfRemembrance: it's the 75th anniversary of the executive order that led to the mass incarceration of 120,000 Japanese Americans, resulting in the freezing of Japanese Americans' bank accounts, physical and verbal assaults, loss of livelihood and possessions, forced separation of families, public demonization, and ultimate imprisonment without due process of law. 

When innocent U.S. citizens—infants and elders, Republicans and Democrats alike—were so easily stripped of their constitutional protections, it was a failure of democracy that jeopardized everyone's security, a failure that should never be repeated.
link_name: What's in a Word? History, Violence, and Erasure When the Words Are 'Japanese Internment' and 'Muslim Registry' - Rewire

status_message:
Dr. Maya Angelou's life could not be contained by a single autobiography, so she wrote six. 

Angelou's multi-volume "song of herself"—to play off Whitman's famous poem—made an audacious claim: that she, as a Black woman reared in the segregated South, was fully human and a worthy historical subject who needed no outside narrator to tell or validate her story.

#BlackHistoryMonth

status_message:
In Colorado, a bill to ban fetal tissue research at the state's universities failed this week.  

What is worrisome is that the bill itself refers to fetal tissue as "human body parts." That phrase, along with "baby body parts," has been used by Republican lawmakers on the state and federal level in a coordinated smear campaign against Planned Parenthood. In fact, the man who allegedly killed three people at a Colorado Springs Planned Parenthood clinic in 2015 also spoke of "baby parts" when he was arrested. 

It is deeply disturbing that Republican lawmakers adopt the inflammatory and deceptive language and myths message-tested by the anti-choice lobby, language and myths that have incited murderous, terroristic violence.

A 6-year-old exposed to trauma has a brain that looks different from that of a 6-year-old not exposed to trauma. Dr. Elizabeth Fitelson is exploring the links between trauma, mental health, and domestic violence: "It doesn't take much digging to see what's there is trauma, layers and layers of trauma." 

Trauma, including that stemming from domestic abuse, can have lasting neurobiological consequences. At a recent conference on domestic violence, researchers talked about the implications.

status_message:
Live from NYC rally at The Stonewall Inn: #WeResist!

Watch and share:

Rosa Parks was truly a revolutionary Black feminist organizer.
Though she's chiefly known for her radical refusal to move to the back of the bus, setting off the historic 1955 Montgomery bus boycott, her actual work and its impact on the humanity of Black women and girls in the face of overt sexual violence is not widely discussed.

In 1944, Parks organized others in her community to protect and defend Black women and girls against violations of sexual assault in the Jim Crow South. As branch secretary of the Montgomery NAACP, she investigated the acts of rampant sexual violence committed against Black women. For many years, she led local and national coalitions, created national media opportunities, and urged Black women to "speak out" in the struggle against sexual violence.

Some #BlackHistoryMonth intersectionality:
link_name: The Real Work of Rosa Parks: Not Just Refusing to Move to the Back of the Bus, But Combating Sexual Violence - Rewire

status_message:
"As a trans person, my abortion saved my life."

Jack had never wanted children, never wanted to get pregnant, and described their unintended pregnancy at age 21 as "out of body, an incomprehensible trauma." It would be a few years before they realized they were transgender. 

At the time, Jack said, "Though I could see how in someone else, that would feel like a really amazing and beautiful thing and a desirable experience, for me, that was horrific. For me, that was akin to the Alien movies. That was just something that was inherently disturbing to me, and at the time, I didn't understand why."

Hear Jack's story now on CHOICE/LESS: http://rewire.link/2ix89tK
link_name: "As a trans person, my abortion saved my life."

status_message:
Disappointed as she is about her mother's vote for Trump, Anya Alvarez says she sees her as someone who was robbed of opportunity, because no one told her she had a choice. 

"My mother walked a separate path from me, one riddled with obstacles and abuse. There were no reinforcers in her life that made her believe her dreams mattered, that body autonomy mattered, and that how men talk about women is a reflection of how they view them. 

With that in mind, I can't help but believe that this affected her decision immensely. Had she been raised to believe that she also matters, perhaps she would have seen that when men continue to get a pass on their misogyny and prejudice, it makes it that much harder for women to expect equality."
link_name: My Mother and I Are Both Sexual Assault Survivors, But She Voted for Donald Trump - Rewire

status_message:
"When I found out that I was pregnant I sent an email to like 20 some people that was a bcc list of my closest friends and family. It just was like, 'Hey guys, I'm pregnant. I'm going to have an abortion. I don't foresee this being something that's going to be particularly upsetting, or psychologically damaging, or scary for me but I just wanted to let everyone know so that I don't really, like, feel like I have to have this conversation with each one of you individually, and, um, feel free to check in with me in a couple weeks.' I mean, that's clearly not the email that someone would write who feels that they should be stigmatized or shamed for having an abortion. On the contrary, I knew that I was going to be supported pretty much across the board, and I was."

status_message:
A month after the election, we gathered some of the nation's leading reproductive justice leaders to debrief. From our roundtable:

On Trump's election: "It felt like standing at a glass door and watching a tornado coming toward me, my family, my community, my people, and feeling like there was nothing I could do."

On dismantling the system: "White supremacy is a very, very scary system because what it shows is that it doesn't care about anybody but white men. People of color know this." 

On moving forward: "Abortion funds need volunteers. The advice that I've been giving people is to get involved with the structures that already exist and get in formation."
link_name: 'We Have to Shift the Table of Power': A Q&A With Reproductive Rights and Justice Leaders - Rewire

As has been repeated often, the reality is that it was not lack of law or regulation, but rather lack of enforcement that allowed Kermit Gosnell to carry on for so long. He was found guilty in 2013 and was rightly sentenced.

But in a new docudrama—talk about "fake news"—titled Gosnell, ostensibly to be released in early 2017, the anti-choice movement seeks to revive a long list of disproven claims and outright lies about abortion care in the hopes, it is assumed, that the growing market for falsehoods, conspiracy theories, and propaganda will help make their case for outlawing abortion altogether.

Over the counter contraceptives are a great innovation, but they're no substitute for full insurance coverage of birth control. For one thing, you can't exactly walk into a pharmacy and get an IUD.

status_message:
The free press, a keystone of democracy, is under attack by the incoming president of the United States.

A bright spot: today we learned that one of our supporters is including us in their end of year giving with a generous $10K donation "directly in response to Trump's election and the unique challenges that lie ahead for our country."  

We are so deeply grateful for this tremendous gift, which will be incorporated into our plans to expand state-level reporting in 2017 and to report aggressively on the new administration and its actions.

Please consider adding to this gift. Help us hold our government accountable by making a donation to Rewire today in any amount that is meaningful to you. Your donation, in any size, goes toward independent, fact-based reporting on reproductive and sexual health, rights, and justice, on racial justice and immigration, voting rights, and many other related issues.

Rewire is  a 501 c3 non-profit, so your donation is 100 percent tax-deductible. And we are fiercely independent. In an age of "fake news," reality-based news needs your support.
link_name: Support independent, non-profit, fact-based journalism

status_message:
What's missing from much of the discussion about the two bills in Ohio, one of which Governor Kasich just signed into law, is that BOTH the 6 week abortion and the 20 week abortion ban are unconstitutional.

Ohio's has no exception for rape or incest and gives pregnant people immunity only if they are at risk of death or permanent organ damage. It will hit low-income women, women of color, and young women hard.

status_message:
"Ladies," Sean Hannity is here to tell you not to worry your pretty little heads about your rights. Isn't that a relief?

None of this is "fine."

Prior to the election, Trump issued a letter to anti-choice supporters urging them to join his coalition. In exchange, he vowed that both he and Pence would push opposition to reproductive rights and health "every day we are in the White House."

• Rep. Tom Price (R-GA), Trump's pick for secretary of Health and Human Services, could lead the charge in rolling back the Affordable Care Act's birth control benefit requiring insurance plans to cover contraceptives without cost sharing as a preventive service.
• Andrew Puzder, the selection for labor secretary, authored extreme anti-choice legislation in the '80s that opened the door for more state-level restrictions on abortion.
• Ben Carson, who was chosen to head the Department of Housing and Urban Development, wants to see Roe overturned.
• Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, slated to be the U.S. ambassador to China, signed a state budget to allow him to personally decide whether those seeking Medicaid-funded abortions could have them.
• Scott Pruitt, who was picked to run the Environmental Protection Agency, pushed falsehoods about Oklahoma's forced ultrasound laws to defend them in court during his time as the state's attorney general.
• Betsy DeVos, who was tapped to head the Department of Education, has family charities that have given millions of dollars to fake clinics, known as "crisis pregnancy centers."
link_name: No, Sean Hannity, Our Uteruses May Not 'Be Fine' Under Trump - Rewire

In July, Bresha Meadows, then 14, had been arrested for allegedly shooting her father with his own gun as he slept—the same gun he had often brandished, she said, to keep his own family in line.

The average length of pre-trial detention for juvenile cases is 10-12 days. Bresha will have spent 175 days in detention. Still, when she heard the news this week that she will be tried in juvenile rather than adult court, she said with relief, "Mommy, that means I don't have to go to jail for the rest of my life."

The lawsuits represent a new wave of litigation attacking state-level abortion restrictions as advocates hope to build on this summer's Supreme Court win; of the three lawsuits filed, it is the North Carolina case challenging a ban on abortions after 20 weeks that could have the biggest effect on the national abortion rights landscape.
link_name: Pro-Choice Legal Offensive Launched in Three States - Rewire

status_message:
The continual framing of adoption as an unqualified good is not only inaccurate, but also damaging. Such depictions gloss over the real grief of birth parents and the real challenges faced by adoptees, oversimplify the complex socioeconomic reasons that women consider and pursue adoption, stigmatize young mothers who raise their children, and impose an external value system on women's reproductive choices. In this way, the exaltation of adoption is no different than the condemnation of abortion—any cultural narrative promoting or dismissing a single reproductive choice is inherently troubling.

With National Adoption Awareness Month drawing to a close, Gretchen Sisson, a researcher who studies adoption, and Susan Dusza Guerra Leksander, an adoption professional who is also an adoptee and a birth/first* mother, urge people to reconsider our culture's portrayals of adoption.
link_name: Open Adoption Is More Complicated Than Picture Painted by Media, the Industry - Rewire

status_message:
Robert Dear, the admitted Colorado Springs Planned Parenthood shooter, has repeatedly said he wants a trial, that he knows what he did, and that the attack on the clinic was justified because it would prevent the "greater evil" of legal abortion. 

One year later, families and co-workers of the victims are no closer to justice, as a judge has ruled three times that Dear's delusions are so severe that he cannot meet the lenient standard for legal competency in Colorado. That standard is simply whether or not Dear, at this present time, is able to understand the charges against him and to participate in his own defense.
link_name: A Year After the Colorado Planned Parenthood Shootings, Still No Trial in Sight - Rewire

status_message:
Where is the GOP getting the money for its $1.6 million witch hunt against Planned Parenthood? 

When we asked the panel's chair, Rep. Marsha Blackburn (R-TN), in July about the source of the investigation's funding, she punted to House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI). status_message:
"When the day finally came, my husband and I had our plan, directions, and instructions on what to bring and wear. Still, I wasn't really prepared. I'd heard about bombings and shootings at Planned Parenthood facilities on the news. But I wasn't ready for the police and security at the door during what was, for me, an already horrible, scary, and extreme life event. I felt like a criminal going into a secret place in the early hours of the morning. 

I hadn't seen up close how our laws try to shame women. I'd read policy papers about lawmakers forcing women to listen to their fetuses' heartbeat before an abortion, but there I was faced with signing the paper asking me if I 'chose to not see my baby before it was aborted.' I broke down. I was not 'choosing' to do this. What was going on? Was this real life?"
link_name: My Second-Trimester Abortion Wasn't a 'Choice' I Wanted to Make, and Politics Made It Harder - Rewire

Megan Smith and Shaya French address white feminists: "Many of us know what it is like to live without abortion access and we know what it is like to have to fight for reproductive autonomy. But many of us do not know what it is like to have to do that while living with the constant danger of racism, fearing for the lives and safety of our children, or living in communities whose reproductive lives are targeted and restricted in many interconnected ways.

White women have historically sought to secure their own reproductive health at the cost of women of color. We need to recognize that we are in this struggle together, and we can't win by leaving our sisters and siblings behind. We must support reproductive justice organizations led by women of color."

status_message:
Trump has not held a press conference since winning the presidency. Now, however, he wants a "cordial" relationship with the press. This week, for example, Trump met with executives and anchors from CBS, NBC, ABC, CNN, MSNBC, and Fox News, during which he reportedly complained about their coverage of him to date, going so far as to criticize which photos they used. 

Establishing a "cordial" relationship with Donald Trump is not the media's job. Quite the opposite: The highest and primary obligation of journalism is to serve the public interest, and to offer reporting that is fair, accurate, and thorough.
link_name: Media Watch: Trump Is Trying to Control the Press, and We Must Not Let Him - Rewire

status_message:
Troubling similarities between Trump and Turkey's President Erdogan: signs of the repressive regime to come?

After Donald Trump's election in the United States, reports began to surface about increased numbers of hate crimes. Similarly, dozens of women interviewed by Rewire in Istanbul said the number of violent attacks and sexual harassment against them have increased, especially on public transportation. 

Erdogan's Justice and Development Party has suspended, fired, or jailed tens of thousands of Turkish citizens in a post-coup purge. Just last week, 370 organizations, including women's rights groups, were closed down under various charges levied by the government.

Most press outlets that aren't government mouthpieces have been shut down, or their staff replaced with pro-government employees.
link_name: Turkish Citizens Raise Concerns About the Potential for Similar Repression Under Trump - Rewire

status_message:
Trans Awareness Week began on Monday, and culminates today with Trans Day of Remembrance, when those who have lost their lives to transphobic violence are honored and mourned.

For the past three years, however, some activists have spent November 20 celebrating instead, holding a Trans Day of Resilience to go beyond remembrance by emphasizing the strength and resistance of trans and gender-nonconforming communities of color. Check out the gorgeous art project, called "Femifesto," which focuses on trans liberation and touches on subjects as wide-ranging as the detainment of trans people of color by the immigration system and the intricacies of nonbinary lives.
link_name: Trans Day of Resilience Shifts the Narrative of Trans Lives - Rewire

status_message:
Notes from the resistance, from an abortion provider who went to work the day after the election:

"On the day after Donald Trump won the presidency, my patients were similar to any other day. 

There was a 24-year-old Black mother of two, who, until calling out sick for this procedure, hadn't taken a day off of work since her baby was born six months ago. 

Then there was a 19-year-old student who had just started college, the first member of her family to attend a university. 

One patient was a recent immigrant who had an ankle monitor in place, at high risk of being deported in the coming months and separated from her husband and two children.

I'll continue to fight for the rights that I believe in and support, and to reject the kind of hatred and fear that landed Mr. Trump in the White House."
link_name: The Day After the Election, I Went Back to Work as an Abortion Provider, and I Won't Stop

status_message:
In the immediate future, abortion rights are tenuously safe, even with Trump appointees on the Supreme Court. There is currently no case in the pipeline that directly challenges either Roe v. Wade, or Planned Parenthood v. Casey's sloppy undue burden standard.

All of that would change if Congress passed a 20-week abortion ban, a dilation and evacuation abortion and miscarriage management procedure ban, and/or a fetal personhood bill. Any of these possibilities would directly challenge Roe v. Wade. 

The same is not true for transgender rights. Almost immediately after the election results were in, the Trump team announced its plans to rescind the Obama administration's agency actions protecting transgender rights both in the workplace and in schools. Moreover, one trans discrimination suit is currently before the Supreme Court. 

For progressives, the prospect of a Trump judiciary should be terrifying.
link_name: What Happens to Abortion and Trans Rights in the Courts Under a Trump Administration? - Rewire

A 13-year-old Filipino girl was approached by a fellow student she didn't know at her Texas elementary school who said, "You're Asian, right? When they see your eyes you are going to be deported."

A high-school teacher in Georgia was left a note in class telling her that her Muslim headscarf "isn't allowed anymore" with a suggestion that she hang herself with it. The note was signed, "America."

The week following Trump's election, these are just two of the alarming incidents reported to the Southern Poverty Law Center, which is going to be very, very busy in the coming four years.
link_name: A Preview of Trump's America? Hate-Based Incidents Spike Nationwide - Rewire

status_message:
Just a week after the election, Pennsylvania's Senate is reportedly planning a vote on a dangerous bill that was shelved earlier this year criminalizing the safest method of second-trimester abortion and miscarriage management.

Around the country, lawmakers with no medical training frequently propose method bans to criminalize the safest, medically proven procedures. They then threaten to imprison doctors if they provide less-than-optimal care for their patients.

status_message:
Of the nearly 10,000 people locked up on Rikers Island each day, nearly 80 percent have not been found guilty of any crime. More than half of these pre-trial detainees are on New York City's island-jail complex because their families cannot afford bail amounts of less than $1,000. 

Rikers, a new documentary by journalist Bill Moyer, is the first documentary to tell the experiences of New York City's infamous jail solely through the voices of those who have spent years there.
link_name: Documentary About New York City's Island-Jail Complex 'Represents What Rikers Truly Is' - Rewire

status_message:
"Following his stunning victory, there is now almost no one who fails to take President-elect Trump seriously.

We do need, however, to take him literally as well—not in order to mock his ideas that seem fanciful or implausible, but to understand exactly what could now unfold in this country. 

Instead of assuming that Trump cynically described plans to deport millions of immigrants, to target refugees and immigrants based on their religion, to punish women for having an abortion should it become illegal, and to rip up decades-old international agreements that form the basis of what has been a historic period of global stability in order to excite supporters, we should take him at his word.

Time and again, people have written off the stated plans of leaders who turned out to be fascists and dictators, choosing to believe they could not or would not do the outlandish things they said they had planned." - Sharona Coutts
link_name: We Must Take Trump and His Supporters Seriously and Literally

status_message:
Texas' "funerals for fetuses" proposal would require that all miscarriages and abortions be cremated or buried. 

As one woman testified, if the proposed regulation were in effect she would not have sought medical care during her two miscarriages because disposing of the fetal remains would have been too expensive. 

It's not about health. It's about finding ever more creatively cruel ways to punish people for their pregnancy outcomes.
link_name: Texas 'Fetal Remains' Rule Meets Public Resistance - Rewire

Pedro Salmerón Salmerón was picked up in January raids as part of Operation Border Guardian, an immigration enforcement policy primarily targeting Central American migrants who came to the United States as unaccompanied children after January 2014 and have since turned 18. 

Pedro Salmerón Salmerón, of the #NC6, could be deported on TODAY if DHS does not intervene. He was attacked and threatened by gang members before fleeing El Salvador as a refugee. Pedro is a talented musician and a dedicated student at Vance High School. Call Dep. Secretary Mayorkas TODAY and tell him to stop Pedro's deportation and release him to his family in Charlotte. 

Pedro has been in detention (aka jail) for months and now is in the process of being deported to dangerous conditions — read more about Operation Border Guardian at this link: http://rewire.link/2cyHsBV, and take action as Alerta Migratoria NC describes, below!

status_message:
California's Proposition 60 mandates that porn performers wear condoms on set. Looks reasonable at first glance, but a further examination shows that the proposition is rife with problems.

For instance, when people view a porn scene and don't see a condom, they may be unaware of all the invisible safety precautions performers are taking, including consistent and effective testing regimens, says porn performer Andre Shakti. Active porn performers get tested an average of 26 times per year.
link_name: Proposition 60 Ignores Unique Needs of Porn Industry, Perpetuates Falsehoods - Rewire

status_message:
Last week Donald Trump made a promise to Black voters to be their "greatest champion," offering them a "new deal" based on three promises: "safe communities, great education, and high-paying jobs."

Hours after rallying for the Black vote in the battleground state of North Carolina, Trump reportedly kicked a Black man out of the rally, calling him a "thug."

And Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton details several steps on how she would dismantle the school-to-prison pipeline on her website, by providing $2 billion in funding to reform disciplinary policies in schools, hiring school climate support teams for districts that have higher suspension and arrest rates, expanding evidence-based behavioral support programs, increasing the number of teachers of color, and providing training on classroom climate and restorative justice.

However, advocates say neither presidential candidates has a comprehensive plan to disrupt the school-to-prison pipeline.
link_name: Presidential Candidates' Approaches to School-to-Prison Pipeline Fall Short, Advocates Say - Rewire

status_message:
"Get over it," John Schwada said, in response to our query about safety and privacy concerns.

Siouxsie Q commented that members of the public may believe workers are hyperbolizing when they express concerns about overzealous fans, stalkers, and hate groups, but they're not. In her advocacy work, she commented that she regularly encounters performers who have received hate and death threats.

"It's infuriating and heartbreaking," she said, describing the sense of not being heard while working in the industry. She, like other performers, is concerned about how the election rhetoric surrounding Proposition 60 has a stigmatizing effect by suggesting that the porn industry is a hotbed of STIs threatening public health, and infantilizing performers by making it seem as though they can't make decisions about their own sexual health.

status_message:
In 2013, the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis celebrated its 50th anniversary season. None of the plays produced that season were written by women. Abbey Theatre in Dublin celebrated its 110-year anniversary in 2014. There were no plays by women produced that season. 

This is why Guerrilla Girls On Tour! used to publish a "girlcott" list, urging audiences to avoid theaters that do not produce any plays by women and to place Guerrilla Girls stickers on the inside of the theaters' bathroom stalls. 

In her new biography, one Guerrilla Girl takes off her mask to tell her story.

Lorena Peña, the current president of the Legislative Assembly, is  a longtime activist in the leftist FMLN party and co-founder of the feminist organization Las Melidas.

status_message:
While the title of the visually stunning 13TH documentary invokes the 13th Amendment—which abolished slavery after the Civil War with the exception as "punishment for a crime"—director Ava DuVernay doesn't oversimplify the cause of mass criminalization as simply a need for cheap labor. 

Instead, through montages of historical images and footage, as well as interviews with many advocates, she lays out the ways in which social control morphed post-slavery from the Black Codes, to segregation and Jim Crow laws, to the "tough on crime" legislation fueling today's mass incarceration.
link_name: '13th' as a Call—and a Tool—to Connect the Past and Present of Mass Incarceration - Rewire

status_message:
Early voting is underway in Minnesota, where Ilhan Omar—intersectional feminist, Somali-American Muslim immigrant, and winner of the state's DFL primary race—is about to become the nation's first Somali-American legislator. Her Republican opponent has dropped from the race and she is now running unopposed, but the real battle in this DFL-dominated district was the primary battle.

As a woman of color, people told her she would not be able to raise money and win the election.

"Those people were wrong, and I want every young woman of color out there to know that they have the power—and support—to run for office and win," Omar said.
link_name: Somali-American Activist Ilhan Omar Makes History During Minnesota Democratic Party Primary - Rewire

A week after a record 2,000 educators came to work wearing Black Lives Matter t-shirts in Washington state's largest school district, some in Seattle are hopeful that change is on the way for greater equity and access at Seattle Public Schools. 

"It meant a special bond with the community for me because teachers and students came together to show what it means when we say Black Lives Matter," said 17 year old Precious Manning, president of the Black Student Union at Seattle's Chief Sealth International High School. "It told me that those teachers are fighting for our definition of an international school." 

#BlackLivesMatterAtSchool

The pregnancy still growing inside nurse Julie Pineda is infected with the Zika virus that scientists say caused thousands across Latin America to be born with microcephaly, a birth defect in which babies' undersize heads hide severe brain abnormalities. This is a cause of great fear. 

But she lives with another fear as well: Pineda feared that if she miscarried the baby, she might be accused of having had an abortion—a crime in El Salvador that could put her behind bars for up to 50 years.
link_name: Where Women with Zika Fear Prison

status_message:
Advocates are confident that a new federal law guaranteeing a "bill of rights" for sexual assault survivors will serve as a model for state legislatures to standardize their oftentimes haphazard responses. Under the "bill of rights" section, law enforcement officials must preserve a rape kit, evidence collected during a forensic examination, for the duration of an assault's statute of limitations, notifying a survivor in writing 60 days prior to destroying or disposing of it. Oh, and survivors cannot be charged for the rape kit examination. 

Most sexual assaults fall under state and local purview, putting the onus on the state legislatures to follow suit with their own versions of the law.
link_name: Advocates: Sexual Assault Survivors' Bill of Rights Coming to State Legislatures - Rewire

status_message:
'Pussies in Formation': Women Block Trump Tower in Protest of GOP Presidential Nominee, by Auditi Guha 

More than 80 multiracial women marched to Trump Tower Wednesday morning in New York City and called for a rejection of the Republican presidential nominee, citing decades of anti-woman, anti-immigrant, and anti-Black policies supported by the Republican Party.

The activists, many of them survivors of sexual assault, wore black and carried signs with pictures of cats baring teeth that read "Pussies in Formation," "This Pussy Votes," and "Hands Off Our Cuntry." They held hands and blockaded the doors to Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue while chanting "GOP, hands off me," and "Donald thinks he runs this town, pussy came to shut it down." 

"We made it clear our bodies are ours and that the GOP needs to back off," said Agunda Okeyo, a New York City-based writer, filmmaker, and activist who took part in the protest.

"As a proud Chicana and a survivor of sexual assault, I'm appalled not only by the GOP's 50-plus years of misogyny and racism, but also that they continue to support this sexual predator for president," sais Jodeen Olguín-Tayler, an organizer of the protest and vice president of Demos and Demos Action.

Read more: http://rewire.link/2ddq8C3

#PussiesInFormation AllofUs2016
link_name: Pussies in Formation

status_message:
While Trump called Mexican immigrants "criminals" and "rapists," and then broadened his attack to encompass all Latino immigrants, the GOP leadership, which has persistently blamed immigrants for unrelated economic problems to stoke white anger, stayed silent. 

When, as the official GOP nominee, Trump "courted" white supremacist groups and blamed people of color for the outcomes of racist policing, the GOP establishment stayed silent because, in part, its power relies on suppressing the Black vote. When Trump attacked a U.S. judge because of his Mexican heritage, the GOP establishment stayed silent.

When Donald Trump claimed he would "punish" women who had abortions, the GOP leadership, which has spent more time and money at the state and national level passing laws to regulate women's bodies than to educate children or accomplish virtually any other pressing goal, stood by him.

While Trump wants to corner women and probe their bodies with his hands for personal gratification, the GOP wants to probe and control women's bodies for their ideological and political gratification. 

So why was last week's "sex tape" the end? It has nothing to do with "locker room talk," to which I am sure even Mike Pence is no stranger.

Instead, Trump violated a key tenet of the GOP's Madonna-Whore complex: "Hands off married white women."
link_name: All the President's Misogynists: Why It Took So Long to Derail the Trump Train - Rewire

Republicans are scrambling to distance themselves from Trump's latest sexist comments that surfaced late last week, most of them invoking their female relatives. 

But "it shouldn't take having a wife, or a daughter, or a friend to be able to understand and say that this is wrong and it's inexcusable, any more than you'd have to be a Muslim or a Latino or a disabled person to be able to understand and say that the way Trump disrespects members of those communities is absolutely wrong," says Marge Baker with People For the American Way

Empathy for a woman's perspective should not depend on the fact that she is some man's mother, daughter, or wife.
link_name: Trump's Bragging About Sexual Assault Brings Chaos to Congressional GOP - Rewire

status_message:
In a video released by the Washington Office on Latin America last month, viewers learn the story of "Gabriela." 

Forced by a Honduran gang to work in a brothel, the 14-year-old says after she refused to date one of the gang's leaders, she was shot twice. Shortly thereafter, fearing for her life, she decided to make the journey to the United States to reunite with her mother. In Mexico, she was detained by Mexico's National Migration Institute, the institution in charge of migration enforcement operations. 

Instead of providing those seeking safety with needed resources and support, both Mexico and the U.S. have focused on increasing border enforcement, exposing migrants like Gabriela—from the Northern Triangle countries, including El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras—to further violence.
link_name: New Report Details How Central American Migrants Become 'Victims of Mexico' - Rewire

status_message:
In the 16 years since the first edition of "When Love Hurts" was first published, many things have gotten worse for people experiencing intimate partner abuse. Cutbacks in social services mean that women in the United States and Canada are now routinely turned away from shelters because there are not enough beds, for instance. 

And technology has also had a negative impact. Fifteen or 20 years ago, if a woman left a relationship, she could more easily separate emotionally. Now, he can put stuff up on Facebook or constantly text her. If there are children in common, the courts may expect her to respond to each and every one of his messages.
link_name: Swimming in the Waters of Patriarchy: A Q&A With Anti-Domestic Abuse Advocate Karen McAndless-Davis - Rewire

status_message:
"At 17 years old, I served on my first panel to discuss my experiences with sexual assault. When introducing me, the moderator explained, 'Anya Alvarez, a victim of sexual assault, will share her story today.'

As soon as the word 'victim' came out of the moderator's mouth, I felt a sense of immediate sadness and grief. I felt like I had suddenly lost control of the steering wheel: as if I was being pulled back into the moments when I was raped and molested.

There is a way to talk about abuse in a way that does not diminish what happened, while also empowering those affected. More importantly, this does not mean that media can't highlight the severity of the attack and what a grotesque and inhumane act it is."
link_name: Why I'm Not a 'Victim' of Sexual Assault - Rewire

status_message:
For Duane Buck, simply being Black meant an automatic death sentence in Texas' court system. 

 his trial over two decades ago, Duane Buck's own attorney inexplicably put a defense expert psychologist on the stand who testified that Buck was more likely to commit future acts of violence because he is Black. In Texas, a person is subject to the death penalty only if they are dangerous and likely to commit future criminal acts of violence. Buck's defense attorney practically signed his death warrant.
link_name: Supreme Court Hears Argument About Racial Bias in Death Penalty Case - Rewire

status_message:
Meet the man who would be Vice President: 

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has eagerly signed laws aimed at criminalizing abortion, forcing women to undergo unnecessary ultrasounds, banning coverage for abortion care in private insurance plans, and forcing doctors performing abortions to seek admitting privileges at hospitals (a requirement the Supreme Court recently struck down as medically unnecessary). 

He signed a "religious freedom" law that would have legalized discrimination against LGBTQ persons and only "amended" it after a national outcry. Because Pence has guided public health policy based on his "conservative values," rather than on evidence and best practices in public health, he presided over one of the fastest growing outbreaks of HIV infection in rural areas in the United States.
link_name: In Mike Pence, Trump Has Found a Fellow Huckster

The first woman known to die of an unsafe illegal abortion after the Hyde Amendment was a Latina. A struggling 27-year-old college student with a young daughter, Rosie Jimenez died from septic shock on this date in 1977—with a scholarship check earmarked for school in her purse. 

"We cannot afford to sit out voting," write Latina leaders of the reproductive justice movement. "It is an opportunity to make sure that those who are charged with representing us stand with our families. We owe it to Rosie Jimenez and the daughter she left behind. We owe it to ourselves."

status_message:
Cynthia Greenlee reflects: "I had thought that as a 'good' progressive and a 'woke' Black person, I could see Keith Lamont Scott's complexity without blinders and bias. But no matter what Scott carried—a blunt, a book, a gun, or a police record—his death showed me what I and many Americans still carry: the idea that you can behave your way into safety and an acceptance. 

But what I realize now is that state violence goes so deep, it may take my lifetime—and certainly longer than Scott's—to excavate it."

Only two new antibiotics were approved in the United States between 2008 and 2012. And that's a big problem, as more and more illness-causing germs are getting harder to treat with existing medications.

In fact, at a meeting held in Atlanta at the same time the UN was meeting in New York, the CDC announced that seven men in Hawaii were infected with strains of gonorrhea that were showing resistance to the only two drugs we have left to treat it.

status_message:
The wage gap between Black and white workers is wider today than it was nearly four decades ago.

Even with the same education, work experience, metro status, and region of residence, Black men in 2015 made 22 percent less than their white male counterparts—and Black women earned 34.2 percent less than white male workers.
link_name: Study: Black-White Wage Gap Worse Today Than It Was in 1979 - Rewire

status_message:
Why in the 21st century do we still need a day of action for safe abortion? Who are abortions safe and legal for in today's world, and who defines what is "safe" and what is "legal"? Are abortions accessible for people who have mobility or sight challenges, sex workers, or those with nonconforming sexual or gender identities? What about for adolescents who must seek parental notification, those who must pay the equivalent of their monthly wages for an abortion, and undocumented people trying to find an abortion provider in Texas?

Answering these questions requires going beyond the "safe and legal" frame.
link_name: Destigmatizing and Decriminalizing Abortion: That's Our Collective Work - Rewire

status_message:
The rate of abortion in countries where abortion is a crime or permitted only to save a woman's life is around 37 for every 1,000 women, as compared with 34 in countries where abortion is available on request. Progress has stalled.

And where abortion is a crime, it is also unsafe: every hour of every day, eight women die of unsafe abortion. 

September 28 is the Global Day of Action for Access to Safe and Legal Abortion—follow hashtags #Sept28 and #SafeAbortion on social media to learn more.
link_name: Abortion in Developing Regions: What Progress Since 1990? - Rewire

status_message:
Through the Indian Health Care Improvement Act, Native Americans are entitled to care provided by the United States government.

Delivered by a tribe or the Indian Health Service (IHS) division of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, this care is meant to cover a Native American woman's health care throughout her lifetime, including her own birth, her childhood vaccines, and as she matures, her reproductive health care. This insurance—this promise, if you will—provides a range of services relating to contraception, pregnancy, and safe infant delivery.

In her work caring for Native American women relying on federally provided insurance in northern Arizona, Dr. Katherine Glaser meets patients who are shocked when they learn that abortion care is not covered. They are accustomed to receiving care through the Indian Health Service and the centuries-old promise that tribes will have a special government-to-government relationship with the United States.

More from Dr. Glaser:
link_name: For Native Women Seeking Abortion, Hyde Amendment Is Another Broken Promise - Rewire

status_message:
More than 750 people gathered at Freedom Plaza in Washington, D.C., for a vigil on September 19, 2016 to commemorate the lives of people of color lost to ongoing violence, as part of a national summit hosted by the We Won't Wait 2016 campaign. The campaign is a nonpartisan effort representing and advocating for the economic agenda of women of color and low-income women. 

Lucia McBath, mother of Jordan Davis, holds up a photo of her son, a teenager who was killed by gun violence, as she was comforted by Alicia Garza, the co-creator of Black Lives Matter.

"My son would be alive today had it not been for the loose and destructive gun laws in America that allow vigilantism…where the shooter can cry that he fears for his life as a means of justifying unconscionable behavior, as a gun becomes a tool for carrying out his implicit biases towards someone who doesn't think, look, or act like him," said McBath. 

More photos from the vigil: http://rewire.link/2ddAJCQ

status_message:
Many state prison systems allow private companies to exploit prison labor. 

Haystack Mountain, which produces goat cheese, pays Colorado prisoners 66 cents a day to milk approximately 1,000 goats. Baskets of these cheeses sell for $49 to $89 online. The Colorado minimum wage is $8.31 an hour.

Last week people in prisons across the US went on strike—a culmination of the many frustrations experienced by incarcerated people, not only about exploitative prison labor practices, but about inhumane prison conditions in general.
link_name: Paid Pennies for Their Work, Those Behind Bars Go on Strike

status_message:
This week sociologist Carole Joffe rounded up some of Phyllis Schlafly's most notorious statements:

• On marital rape: "By getting married, the woman has consented to sex, and I don't think you can call it rape." 

• On sexual harassment: "Noncriminal sexual harassment on the job is not a problem for the virtuous woman except in the rarest of cases."

• On domestic violence: "When marriages are broken by false allegations of domestic violence, U.S. taxpayers fork up an estimated $20 billion a year to support the resulting single-parent, welfare-dependent families."

• On feminist candidates for office: "Feminists are having a hard time being elected because they essentially are unlikable."

• On the gender wage gap: "The best way to improve economic prospects for women is to improve job prospects for the men in their lives, even if that means increasing the so-called pay gap."
link_name: The Legacy—or Lack Thereof—of Phyllis Schlafly - Rewire

status_message:
A Catholic hospital sent a miscarrying woman home, bleeding and in pain—twice!—refusing to treat her. The third time she returned to the hospital she was suffering from infection from her untreated miscarriage. Staff gave her an aspirin and prepared to send her home again, but before the hospital discharge process was complete, she started to deliver her dying fetus.

Mercy Health Partners risked Tamesha Means' life and health in order to adhere to Catholic ethical and religious directives, which are expressions of religious belief—not the same thing as professional standards of care.

Yet an appeals court refuses to allow her to sue for medical negligence.
link_name: Appeals Court Won't Hold Catholic Hospital Responsible for Denial of Care - Rewire

status_message:
"The day I stood next to my son's birth mother in the operating room for her C-section and together we heard our son cry for the first time was the best day of my life – and it reinforced to me why adoption must be a choice and no one should ever be forced to carry a pregnancy to term. 

My family was created through open adoption. It's no coincidence birth parents gained much more power in adoption after Roe v. Wade legalized abortion in the United States. The work I do is about more than abortion rights, it's about ensuring that every pregnant person is able to make the best decision they can for themselves and their families – whether that is abortion, parenting or making an adoption plan. My experience with infertility, as a foster parent and creating my family through open adoption has only strengthened my resolve to work to ensure that all pregnant people have self-determination and all pregnancy choices are honored and supported."

—Nikki Madsen, Executive Director, Abortion Care Network

More stories of pro-choice parents: http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/

Share your story: http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/submit
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"It's very jarring when you're sitting in front of somebody who's about to have their abortion and they say to you, 'I don't believe in abortion, but I need this,'" Dr. Leah Torres said. She's had patients, their feet in the stirrups, tell her that what she does is evil. 

"What I usually respond with is, 'I understand—and, you know, no one ever plans to be in this position. But we're going to take really good care of you. Because that's our job.'"
link_name: What Is It Like to Be an Abortion Provider in an Anti-Choice State?

status_message:
Although girls may have equal opportunities on paper, they are often still relegated to second-class treatment when it comes to sports.

"At a high school level, we have zero attention to equal access to facility—that's a funding thing. How you spend your money [and on which facilities] is an expression of what you care about. Right now, we're sending the message that we don't care about developing female athletes," noted Jessica Mason Pieklo, Vice President of Law and the Courts at Rewire.
link_name: Rio Showed Us Where Title IX Has Succeeded—But Equality in Sports Still Has Far to Go - Rewire

status_message:
Local court and law enforcement systems in small counties throughout the United States are increasingly using jails to warehouse underserved Black and Latina women: the number of women in jails based in communities with under 250,000 residents has grown a whopping 31-fold since 1970.

Historically, jails were designed to hold people not yet convicted of a crime or people serving terms of one year or less, but they are increasingly housing poor women who can't afford bail.
link_name: What's Driving Women's Skyrocketing Incarceration Rates? - Rewire

status_message:
Melanie Jones arrived for her doctor's appointment bleeding and in pain. Jones, 28, who lives in the Chicago area, had slipped in her bathroom, and suspected the fall had dislodged her copper intrauterine device (IUD). But the doctor said she would be unable to remove the IUD, citing Catholic restrictions followed by Mercy Hospital and Medical Center.

Jones left her doctor's office, still in pain and bleeding. Her options were limited. She couldn't afford a $1,000 trip to the emergency room, and an urgent care facility was out of the question since her Blue Cross Blue Shield of Illinois insurance policy would only cover treatment within her network—and she had just been told that her entire network followed Catholic restrictions.
link_name: Complaint: Citing Catholic Rules, Doctor Turns Away Bleeding Woman With Dislodged IUD - Rewire

Women of color-led organizations began the call for the repeal of the Hyde Amendment — a harmful law that denies access to abortion to those who have public insurance, discriminating against low-income women and, disproportionately, women of color."

status_message:
In honor of Dr. Joycelyn Elders' birthday today, we're sharing her article from five years ago—as pertinent today as it was then.

"When children experience puberty, natural intensification of sexual feelings soon follows. While many adults cringe at simply seeing the words 'adolescent' and 'sexuality' paired together, the adolescent hormonal imperative proceeds with its relentless takeover of youthful thinking—and, often, action.

We need to make sure that when that moment comes, they know how to be safe."
link_name: A Collision of Culture and Nature: How Our Fear of Teen Sexuality Leaves Teens More Vulnerable - Rewire

status_message:
Happy birthday to masturbation defender, straight talker, feminist crusader and first Black US Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders!

Image credit: 4000 Years for Choice 

In 1994, as a progressive thinker and champion of public health, Dr. Elders was forced to resign from her post as Surgeon General after the conservative outcry that resulted when she suggested that one way to help curb the spread of AIDS would be to discuss masturbation with students. She also criticized the Catholic Church for its opposition to abortion and backed the distribution of contraception in public schools.

status_message:
The patient learned she had brain cancer in her first trimester of pregnancy. She needed chemotherapy and abortion care.

"I've got a woman whose life is threatened by brain cancer," her doctor, an OB-GYN at a Catholic hospital, told authorities there. "I need to do a termination."

Catholic hospitals follow religious directives that generally bar certain types of health care, including abortions, except when the patient is in imminent danger.

The hospital refused the treatment, telling the OB-GYN to refer his patient elsewhere.
link_name: Study: Catholic Hospitals 'Dump' Abortion Patients, Often Refuse Referrals - Rewire

status_message:
Reports of deceit by 91% of fake clinics surveyed by NARAL Pro-Choice California helped spur the passage of the FACT Act, which requires unlicensed centers to disclose that they are not medical facilities.

Until recently, a person who Googled "abortion clinic" might be directed to a fake clinic, or crisis pregnancy centers.
link_name: Three Crisis Pregnancy Centers Served for Breaking California Law - Rewire

status_message:
Dr. Debra Stulberg went to medical school knowing she wanted to provide abortion care as part of her practice. But just one year into her medical residency, her hospital was taken over by a Catholic system, and not only could she and her fellow doctors not prescribe birth control or perform tubal ligations, but suddenly they couldn't even treat miscarriages or ectopic pregnancies with what are considered contemporary medical standards. 

This goes on in SO many places. Many times patients don't realize that their hospital is part of a Catholic system until it's too late. Many times it's the only health care option available. 

Listen to Dr. Stulberg's story—it's the last episode of our first season of Choice/Less. All episodes are available on our site and through podcasting app: search for "Choice/Less" on the iTunes store. http://rewire.news/choiceless
link_name: CHOICE/LESS: "Did you hear we're going to be working for the Pope?"

status_message:
Today is the first anniversary of the wrongful death of Sandra Bland while in custody at a Texas jail, arrested during a routine traffic stop on her way back from the job interview she'd aced. 

Activists held a vigil at the jail this year to give voice to Bland and other victims of racism and police brutality. It ended Wednesday morning at approximately 9 a.m., the time when jail officials are said to have discovered that Bland had died in her cell. 

 "Sandy still speaks," an organizer said. "Sandy speaks through us at the Waller County jail."

status_message:
Maria Teresa Rivera was finally freed from prison after serving more than four years in El Salvador, where abortion is a severely-punished crime, for her miscarriage. Now the government is appealing the court's decision to overturn her sentence and she could return to prison.

"I just don't understand the prosecutor's motivation for this appeal," Rivera says. "What most worries me is leaving my son alone again. I was forced to abandon him for four and a half years, and he suffered greatly during that time."
link_name: Freed From a Post-Miscarriage Prison Sentence, El Salvador Woman Could Return to Prison

status_message:
A lawsuit accuses the federal government of paying millions to religious grantees that refuse to provide unaccompanied minors with legally required reproductive health services. Background: Two years ago, 17-year-old Rosa was raped as she fled north from her home country in Central America to the United States. Placed in a Catholic shelter in Florida, the teen learned she was pregnant, and told shelter officials that if she couldn't end the pregnancy, she'd kill herself. Upon her release, the facility in which she'd been originally placed rejected her because of her desire for an abortion, according to a federal lawsuit filed Friday. So did another. Both, reads the lawsuit, were federal contractors paid to care for unaccompanied minors like Rosa. Read the full story here: [Lawsuit: Religious Groups Are Denying Abortion Care to Teen Refugees, by Nicole Knight Shine http://bit.ly/29dbOx8] 

Rewire reader Tamara Rivera had this response:
link_name: Community voices

Two years ago, 17-year-old Rosa was raped as she fled north from her home country in Central America to the United States. Placed in a Catholic shelter in Florida, the teen learned she was pregnant, and told shelter officials that if she couldn't end the pregnancy, she'd kill herself. She was hospitalized for suicidal thoughts. 

Upon her release, the facility in which she'd been originally placed rejected her because of her desire for an abortion, according to a federal lawsuit filed Friday. So did another. Both, reads the lawsuit, were federal contractors paid to care for unaccompanied minors like Rosa.

status_message:
In the 1980s, Juanita Williams learned she was HIV positive when she requested a tubal ligation. Instead of referring her for treatment, the medical team not only refused her tubal ligation, but ushered her down the back staircase and out the door.

National HIV Testing Day is June 27. But for longtime advocates, ensuring that the women most affected by the epidemic can get and influence care and policy is the work of many years.
link_name: 'Not the Enemy, But the Answer': Elevating the Voices of Black Women Living With HIV

status_message: "What, exactly, is the difference between the hatred spewed by radical Islamists and that by Christian fundamentalists in the United States? How can any less responsibility be laid at the feet of the U.S. politicians and their supporters for violence and terror when they espouse the same forms of hatred and marginalization as those they blame for that terror? Why are we so quick to connect the lone gunman in Orlando with Islam and so unwilling to connect the "lone wolves" like Robert Dear, Angie Dillard, and Scott Roeder with the Christian right, or to hold young white star athletes accountable for the violence they perpetrate on women? Why are we so loath to talk about rational limits on an AK-47 assault rifle, a weapon of war, when mass murders have become routine?"

status_message:
In November 2011, Maria Teresa Rivera unexpectedly went into labor, giving birth in the latrine of her home in El Salvador. The birth was dangerous and unattended by any medical professionals; the fetus died. Like many women in El Salvador, where abortion is completely illegal, Rivera's medical crisis led to her being charged with and convicted of aggravated homicide; she was sentenced in 2012 to 40 years in prison.

Today she had a long-anticipated hearing and the judge has just issued a new decision: Maria Teresa Rivera is FREE! 

Read more about her case here: https://rewire.news/article/2016/05/10/sentenced-40-years-miscarriage-maria-teresa-rivera-may-have-chance-to-go-free/

status_message:
AJ would learn that in addition to the anonymous phone calls that had been made to the clinic while she and her daughter waited for her procedure, people unknown to AJ had faxed her daughter's personal information—her name, medical information, and even her social security number—to countless numbers of doctors, police, and other strangers in at least two states, without AJ's knowledge or consent. 

She would discover that her daughter had been picked up from school and driven across the state border by a person that AJ did not know. And before the saga was resolved, AJ would even find out that an attorney she'd never heard of had purported to represent her daughter, and had sent threatening letters to the abortion clinic, directly interfering with her daughter's medical treatment.

Read the report: https://rewire.news/article/2016/03/30/anti-choice-activists-using-bogus-legal-threats-trick-teens-signing-away-abortion-rights/

status_message:
"When I was pregnant with my third child, Texas passed the law that will close all but 8 of its abortion clinics. I headed home to rally at the Capitol, where I set up Progress Playground, a family-friendly spot where we had toys and snacks and quiet space for families with kids. 

We did this because Reproductive Justice is about more than abortion: it's about relationships, love, and family. Being pregnant has made me an even stronger believer that everyone should be free to make decisions about their bodies, and I'm raising my sons to respect and support the decisions people make about their lives and families."

Farah Diaz-Tello, National Advocates for Pregnant Women 

Read more stories of pro-choice parents—or share your own—here: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

status_message:
The most sinister thing about this bill isn't that it equates abortion clinics to sex offenders, though that's awful enough. It requires doctors to disclose their percentage of income obtained from providing abortion services, and a statement "concerning the monetary loss to the abortion provider which would result from the woman's decision to carry the pregnancy to term."

Think about that. Many doctors who provide abortions also deliver babies. Wouldn't the decision to carry the pregnancy to term result in MORE income for a physician?
link_name: Alabama GOP Makes Another Push to Regulate Abortion Clinics Like Sex Offenders

status_message:
I am pro-choice, therefore I am pro-family. The picture below is me, my parents, and my two children supporting our local Planned Parenthood at a rally last fall.

When I was 18, I terminated an unintended pregnancy because I had plans and dreams that that couldn't be fulfilled if I were a teen mom. I have never once regretted it, and am so thankful I live in a place and time that allowed me to make my own choices, choose my own destiny.

Fast forward to me at 33-a proud wife and mother to a 2- and 4-year old, for whom the sun and moon sets. And I'm pregnant. My husband and I chose to terminate the pregnancy because we were already overwhelmed with the difficulties and the joys of parenthood, and the financial strain it causes.

I am now 36. I've had two abortions for very different reasons, and neither have resulted in an ounce of regret, shame, or guilt. I'd make the same decisions again. And, if I were so unfortunate as to not be afforded that right, I'd continue to make my decisions illegally, no matter the risk.

Read more pro-choice parents' stories, and share yours here: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

status_message:
Photojournalist Wendi Kent avoids using the word "shoot" as she takes pictures at abortion clinics nationwide.

While her photographs show predictable tableaux, they underscore the contradiction between protesters' declarations of Christian compassion and their behaviors: yelling, shaming, and metaphorically bludgeoning people with the Bible.

Kent, of Madison, Wisconsin, travels the country for her ongoing "Faces of the Fight" photojournalism project. It's a distinctly different enterprise than other abortion-related photography or visual advocacy, which have tended to focus on rallies, specific political campaigns or measures, or on the stories of women who have had abortions.

From "How Photographer Wendi Kent Hopes to Galvanize the Quiescent 'Pro-Choice Majority,'" by Cynthia R. Greenlee: http://rhrc.us/1JPveE0

Wendi Kent's Facebook page: Wendi Kent Photography

status_message:
South Carolina Rep. Mia McLeod's bill would require that:

• men undergo a 24 hour waiting period when seeking erectile dysfunction medication
• each man present a notarized affidavit from a sexual partner affirming that he has experienced erectile dysfunction in the past 90 days 
• each man receiving a prescription would be required to attend three sessions of outpatient counseling within six months, "including sexual counseling and resources for patients to pursue celibacy as a viable lifestyle choice."
link_name: South Carolina Bill Targets Viagra to Get People Talking About Anti-Choice Laws

Robin is a doctor who provides abortion care at a Midwest clinic a couple of days a week. She's exasperated, and so are we. 

The fact is that doctors wear bulletproof vests, clinics install bulletproof glass, and security guards at abortion clinics—medical clinics!—are ready for events like the one in Colorado because the powers that be in this country have permitted an epidemic of anti-abortion terrorism to flourish.

Since 1977 there have been over 60,000 recorded instances of harassment, intimidation, and violence perpetrated against abortion providers in this country. These figures are likely underreported.

Authors and legal experts David S. status_message:
One story for #NationalAdoptionDay comes from Molly Rampe Thomas:

"My name is Molly Rampe Thomas. I am the founder of Choice Network, a full service adoption agency located on-site at top abortion clinics nationwide.

Unplanned pregnancy rocks worlds. My agency was built around love for the first woman I ever worked with, who happens to be my daughter's biological mother.

Ro faced an unplanned pregnancy and due to her being HIV positive and struggling from addiction, she was desperate to choose abortion. After working hard to find funding for her very late term abortion, we were both relieved when the day of her termination arrived. Full of peace, she entered the doors.

I was shocked to get her call soon after. She was sobbing. She had just found out her original ultrasound was wrong and she was too far along. She needed now to talk about adoption.

I'll never forget her asking, "What do I do now? No one will want my baby." Slowly, but without hesitation, I replied "I do. What if we do this together? What if we create an adoption plan together?" 

And together we did just that.

Our adoption story would be the perfect representation of Choice Network, an agency who believes in women and trusts their choices.  Though it is the hardest work I have ever done, I do it for my daughter Gia and her birth mother.

This month Gia turned 5. She is the spark that started my life. She is everything to me. She is why pro-choice matters."

Read more stories about pro-choice parents here: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

Are you a pro-choice parent? We'd love to share your story!
http://rhrc.us/1GGzbJe
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

"Me with my second son, soon after another powerful healthy homebirth. Pregnancy, childbirth, and mothering have made me more pro-choice than ever–fully 100% no questions asked, keep abortion safe, healthy, non-stigmatized for ALL, access to accurate, positive sexual health education and birth control for ALL. Everyone should have this option."  – Rachel & Leo (photo 2011)

"I've had people ask me if having a child changed my feelings about abortion, or if I would no longer be an abortion provider. If anything, the incredible responsibility of caring for my amazing daughter has made me realize that parenting should be something that is entered into willingly and (ideally) joyfully. I will continue to provide abortions for my patients because a world of wanted children is the kind of world I want my daughter to grow up in."

Diane Horvath-Cosper, MD

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

"I worked at an abortion clinic while I was pregnant with my first child. One of the women who was there to have an abortion asked me if it was difficult emotionally to do the work while carrying a child to term. I told her, "My feet hurt, my hips hurt, my joints are so lax I have to be careful not to sprain my ankles walking, I have to pee constantly, and I'm looking forward to eighteen years of putting someone else first in my life. You better believe I want you to have a choice about doing this for yourself.

She broke out in a big, relieved smile. One of my best memories."

—Ellen Eades

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

My pregnancy was planned to the month. The part you can't plan for is the six months of throwing up and being unable to eat, the multiple emergency room visits for dehydration, the endless rounds of frightening drugs to try to keep nutrients in my body and in the baby's body. The part you can't plan for is the 26 hours of labor, the first big chunk during the biggest storm and power outage in many years. The part you can't plan for is the three hours of pushing so hard the capillaries in my eyes broke. 

Would I do it over again? Absolutely. But NOBODY should have to do it without choosing it. 

I am a parent. I adore my child. And I am completely pro-choice.

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

"My name is Molly Rampe Thomas. I am the founder of Choice Network, a full service adoption agency located on-site at top abortion clinics nationwide.

Unplanned pregnancy rocks worlds. My agency was built around love for the first woman I ever worked with, who happens to be my daughter's biological mother.

Ro faced an unplanned pregnancy and due to her being HIV positive and struggling from addiction, she was desperate to choose abortion. After working hard to find funding for her very late term abortion, we were both relieved when the day of her termination arrived. Full of peace, she entered the doors.

I was shocked to get her call soon after. She was sobbing. She had just found out her original ultrasound was wrong and she was too far along. She needed now to talk about adoption.

I'll never forget her asking, "What do I do now? No one will want my baby." Slowly, but without hesitation, I replied "I do. What if we do this together? What if we create an adoption plan together?" And together we did just that.

Our adoption story would be the perfect representation of Choice Network, an agency who believes in women and trusts their choices.  Though it is the hardest work I have ever done, I do it for my daughter Gia and her birth mother.

This month Gia turned 5. She is the spark that started my life. She is everything to me. She is why pro-choice matters."

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

"My body, my pregnancies, my children, my choices. 

No man, no law, no court and no candidate can decide these things for me.

Reproductive choices about when and how to have children are mine to make, and they are mine to live with forever.

The sacredness of child birthing and parenting has made me all the more committed to the political struggle for full reproductive freedom for every woman, everywhere.

Mothering is the toughest thing I have ever attempted, and I give thanks every day for the blessing, the challenge, and the privilege to create the family I truly want. 

May we rise together as women for a world where our voices and choices are respected."

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

Right after my husband and I first moved in together, I got pregnant. We had not been together long, we were not married, had just moved to a new city, only he was working, and the economy had just tanked - not a great time to enter into parenthood. On top of that, I was only 22 and not only wasn't ready then to be a parent, I didn't think I would ever want to be a parent. I was lucky and had access to safe, affordable abortion care.

Fast forward seven years, I got pregnant again. At first I was scared, but I knew in that moment that I was going to be a parent and I was happy about it. That moment reaffirmed my prochoice beliefs; it wasn't just that we were married, stable, "ready" to be parents by all outward markers - something had changed inside of me. While I could have probably pulled it together and raised a child all those years earlier, I would not have been able to nurture, love, and provide for my baby in the way that I am now. She turns one year old in a couple of months, and we are hoping to add to our family in the next few years.

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

Birth control empowered me to choose the right time in my life to have a baby.

After 10+ years on birth control, I stopped taking the pill when my husband and I decided we were ready to start a family. We were elated when we found out I was pregnant. At our 20-week ultrasound, we were devastated to learn that our daughter had a serious combination of heart defects and would need open heart surgery as an infant. But because we were able to wait to have a baby until we were ready and financially stable, we had the means and resources to get our heart baby the critical care she needed.

Our daughter had her surgery at 5 months old and is now doing wonderfully. I'm so grateful that she came into our lives at the right time, when we were able to support her and to cope with this serious and stressful situation.

I'm a pro-choice parent because all women should be able to make the best decisions for their lives and their families.

—Amy

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

#WCD2015 #BirthControlHelpedMe
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice
