✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

"Having children only deepened and strengthened my lifelong commitment to reproductive justice. If families are to be truly valued in this country, women of all backgrounds must have access to safe, legal, and affordable reproductive health options. 

If the energy and money spent putting up barriers to contraception and abortion access in this country were diverted to feeding, clothing, and housing needy children, 'family values' might be a reality, not a slogan. I'm working towards that vision of America, and my two kids are, too." 

Shannon Drury, author of "The Radical Housewife: Redefining Family Values for the 21st Century"

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

"I have always been pro-choice. I had the honor of spending most of my twenties organizing door-to-door for NARAL Pro-Choice Minnesota and was a fearless advocate for reproductive rights. But it was not until I carried my own planned pregnancy to term and had a daughter of my own that I really understood how much of yourself you give when you have a child.

The trade-off for me has been the greatest love of my life! Having my daughter with my supportive and loving partner has been awesome. But I realize now more than ever that no woman should ever be forced to make this sacrifice unless and until she is ready.

My daughter has the right to choose her own destiny."

Melissa Golke, J.D.

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

"This picture of Medical Students for Choice staff and members at the All Above All rally in Philadelphia captures the ordinariness of my experience of going to work while pregnant. (I'm in the front left, 38 weeks pregnant). 

The really amazing thing is how great it is to parent in a pro-choice office. My co-workers at MSFC hold and love the baby, help me problem-solve parenting troubles, and keep me sane by making a place for me to participate in the important work of the pro-choice movement while I do the important work of parenting.  

My co-workers and I have a daily reminder (in the form of my baby) of how joyful and how difficult parenting can be– we want families of all kinds to be able to decide for themselves when parenting will bring them more joy than difficulty."  

Katie, Director of Membership Engagement, Medical Students for Choice and Vice Chair, Women's Medical Fund Board of Directors

"When I was pregnant with my third child, Texas passed the law that will close all but 8 of its abortion clinics. I headed home to rally at the Capitol, where I set up Progress Playground, a family-friendly spot where we had toys and snacks and quiet space for families with kids. We did this because Reproductive Justice is about more than abortion, it's about relationships, love, and family. Being pregnant has made me an even stronger believer that everyone should be free to make decisions about their bodies, and I'm raising my sons to respect and support the decisions people make about their lives and families."

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

This is me at 36 weeks pregnant with my little boy a year ago. Pregnant and pro-choice! And now I am a parent who's pro-choice! I have worked with Planned Parenthood and NARAL in the past to defend abortion rights and have fought against 3 different personhood amendments here in Colorado.

I experienced a miscarriage of a very wanted pregnancy in 2012. I got pregnant less than a year later and gave birth to my son in June 2014–he is a year old as of yesterday! I experienced discrimination during my pregnancy job-wise and while I got justice, it was a difficult situation.

Although physically I had a very easy pregnancy, his birth was difficult and long, and I cannot imagine ever forcing someone to go through any of it. The experience of becoming a mother has only made me more pro-choice. A life-changing event like parenthood should always be a choice. I love my son dearly, and I am glad my husband and I were able to plan when to expand our family!

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

I've worked for an abortion provider for nearly 11 years. I'm passionate about the work that I do, because (among many other reasons), I feel that the decision to be a mother should be made intentionally.

My babies were joyfully welcomed into my life. They are wanted and loved beyond all reason. They are my gifts, my treasures. Never a mistake, never a burden.

I wish this for every baby that is born. Planned, wanted, and loved!

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

I had two early miscarriages before giving birth to my son in 1997 and then five more before adopting my daughter in 2004. Although I have always been pro-choice, my struggles with infertility deepened my commitment to speaking out for every woman's right to control her reproductive life. Also, as an adoptive parent, I am grateful that my daughter's first mom was able to choose to continue her pregnancy and was not coerced into doing so by legal constraints. 

Now as a counselor working with women around issues of family building, I am committed to offering pro-choice services for my clients as they struggle with all aspects of fertility, pregnancy and parenting. I trust the woman sitting before me to know her self best and whatever decisions she may make, I am honored to bear witness to them and to support her in them.

This is a picture of me writing to meet deadline with my then 2-year old daughter keeping me company.

— My name is Dawn Friedman and I'm proud to be a pro-choice parent.

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

I was never sure I wanted to become a mother at all and I made sure my husband knew that before we were married. Choosing to go off of birth control and see if I became pregnant was nerve-wracking, as was being pregnant, but it was also filled with a tremendous amount of conflicting joy.

I am unabashedly smitten by my daughter and would choose her every day of the week, and then some. But the truth is that I value my role as a mother even more because it was my choice to decide.

The right to legal abortion doesn't exist everywhere. A few years ago, a dear friend had an unwanted pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal. Instead of risking being ostracized by her community and being forced to drop out of university, she had an illegal abortion. In an alley, by an unlicensed physician, putting her own health at risk. Thankfully she survived with no complications, but many women aren't so fortunate. Today she has a family, with children, and a career that fulfills her.

While my friends story might be something that happened in another country, the same thing is happening in America today and quite simply, women's lives are at risk. In Texas, for example, the rates that women are trying to self-abort – yes, self-abort – has skyrocketed because politicians have closed clinics and ignored women.

All of us lead complex lives with different paths, it is not my right to judge what path each woman chooses to take. But thankfully, it is my job to keep fighting for every woman to have the freedom to decide what's best for her.

I will always be grateful for the freedoms that have allowed me to carve the life I lead. And I will continue to fight and organize for those same freedoms for my friend. For my daughter. For every woman. For their right to decide if, when or how to become a mother.

Who's with me?

Sasha Bruce, VP of Campaigns and Strategy, NARAL Pro-Choice America 

Read more stories and share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

I cried, I was worried, this man who made me laugh, now made me cry- he became abusive, it affected my career, and it affected my grades in school. How could I have a child with this abusive man?

Without Planned Parenthood, where would I be today? 

via Humans of Planned Parenthood

status_message:
#tbt ✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice 

My grandmother emigrated to America from Sweden. Her husband drove a bakery truck and she was a seamstress and sewed monograms into furs in Boston. They arrived in the late 1920s. They worked hard, but they were poor for a very long time. 

She had an abortion, and I thank God she survived it, but many didn't. Later, when they'd saved and when she and my grandfather could afford a family, she had one child, a son, my father. I am so proud of her for finding the strength to do what worked for her family at a time when that was not easy to do. I too am pro-choice. 

Read more stories or share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

"Getting pregnant was really difficult. I struggled with infertility and it took many treatments, a good amount of money, and 7 years to become pregnant. The journey was emotional to be sure. 

Once pregnant, I was ecstatic and overwhelmed. It is imperative that we support women at all stages in their life, when a pregnancy is very desired and when it is not. Women need space to make the best decision for them, without adding undue burden to the process. Being a mother is amazing and rewarding, but challenging; and you need to be ready to take on the challenge."

Jacqui Quetal, Family Nurse Practitioner, Co-founder, Nursing Students For Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

I got pregnant when I was 19, single, and in my second semester of college. Anyone who has been there knows how terrifying that is. I found out I was pregnant at a Planned Parenthood after going for a pap smear. 

I will forever be grateful to the nurse who sat down with me as tears streamed down my face and gave me ALL my options without judgment. She provided me with information on local programs for obstetrics care, adoption agencies, and abortion clinics.  

Ultimately, I decided to have my child—a beautiful boy who just turned 10 this weekend (who by the way watched his mom walk for her bachelors and masters degree—education is still attainable while parenting!)  

Parenting was the right choice for me—but the key word is CHOICE. I support a woman's right to choose. Thankfully, we live in a country where we have safe options—making these options illegal would only increase back-alley abortions….we should cherish our woman's health more than that.  Our bodies, our choices. 

Read more stories or share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice
Texas doctor's consent form for women seeking abortions

status_message:

I hope to teach them that not only are reproductive rights human rights, but also that working to make sure that these rights are a reality for all people is a critical piece of promoting reproductive and social justice."

—Divya

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

My daughter and me.  

I am a mother of 4 (3 sons and 1 daughter), and also a women's health nurse. I worked in several Planned Parenthood clinics, in several states, as a clinic and recovery nurse, assisting in abortions and the recovery thereof. I counseled thousands of patients on pregnancy choice. I performed thousands of ultrasound examinations to date pregnancies. I was pregnant with my own babies throughout my career. Never once did a patient seem uncomfortable with or offended by my obvious pregnant belly. I have observed that most women innately understand the concept of "choice."  

There are so many reasons women choose parenthood or abortion.  Each one is personal and is really nobody's business other than the woman's and her partner.

status_message:
✔ Pregnant
✔ Parenting
✔ Pro-Choice

In between having my two children (now 16 and 12) I had an abortion. Newly divorced and struggling to make ends meet for myself and my young son, I knew that I was not equipped to provide for TWO children on my own. Plain and simply, my allegiance was to my child, and not to the group of cells within me with the potential to become a child. I had to make sure that my firstborn would be okay, first and foremost. Years later, when I was in a more stable place and able to hold our head above water, I found out I was pregnant again. I felt confident in my ability to add another child to my household and keep everyone afloat, so I excitedly continued the pregnancy. 

My life is amazing now and my children are beyond what I could have ever expected. My son is a junior in high school with his sights set on college in Germany and later, being a published author and a professor of humanities. My daughter is a straight A student, incredibly driven, and on her way to a successful career in ballet and was accepted into the Joffrey Academy. Because I made the choices I did, I have been able to create a strong space for them to grow and receive the support they need to fulfill their potential. 
 
I regret nothing and if I had it to do over, I'd choose exactly the same way knowing what I know now. I support every woman in making her choices and trust her to know what will work best for her. 

Read more stories or share your own: http://rhrc.us/ProChoiceParents

status_message:
✔ Pregnant ✔ Parenting ✔ Pro-Choice

I am an abortion counselor and have been for 3 years. 7 months ago I gave birth to my first child. 

During my pregnancy I had so many patients and even friends make comments about me being pregnant. "How ironic to work at an abortion clinic and be pregnant!" Or "I don't want the pregnant lady to counsel me." When I heard these comments, it was hurtful and frustrating, but I took it as an opportunity to educate those around me. 

Being pro-choice is about being able to decide IF and WHEN you want to be a parent. I am choosing at this time in my life to be a parent. There was a time in my life when I decided it wasn't the best time for me to have a child. I'm so glad I had the choice and was trusted to make the best decision for myself and for my future family.

Jen

status_message:
✔ Pregnant
✔ Parenting
✔ Pro-Choice

I am the mother to two boys. Experiencing pregnancy and childbirth twice merely reinforced my belief that each woman must decide for herself if it's a journey she wants to go on.

Pregnancy helped me better understand the 'grey' in these choices, which is why no one else should be able to make them. Because my husband and I were ready and wanting to have children, the moment we knew that I was pregnant, our son was a 'baby.' For others, that wouldn't be the case. I could never presume to tell someone else how to feel in that moment.

Both of my pregnancies were relatively easy from a physical standpoint, but I struggled through both due to having a mental health condition. What I didn't realize before my first pregnancy was that the significant hormonal changes would only worsen the anxiety and panic attacks that I had been managing for many years. I also worried about whether to take anti-depressants during my pregnancies. I ultimately decided not to, but the result was nine months of very challenging mental health during each one. I cherish my kids, but I know that I don't want any more. I don't think being pregnant for a third time would be good for me. I am blessed to have access to birth control and a stable life that has allowed me to stick to that plan. But what if I didn't? Or what if it doesn't in the future?

And pregnancy - with its many discomforts, body changes and "rules" - and especially childbirth should never be forced on someone who doesn't want to have the child. It would truly, truly be torture. It's a day in, day out, whole life commitment followed by an excruciating process to deliver the child into this world. It is difficult, uncomfortable and painful for women who are ready, willing and supported. I cannot fathom forcing someone who's not to endure that.

For these reasons and more, experiencing pregnancy made me believe even more deeply that only women, their families and their doctors should decide how to handle a pregnancy. There is no black and white here; there is only grey. No lawmaker should attempt to tell women how to handle that grey.

To see more stories and add your own, click here: http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant
✔ Parenting
✔ Pro-Choice

I was 19 when I got pregnant with boy Maxie. At the time my boyfriend lived out of the city, so I knew I had to evaluate my choices when it came to my pregnancy and being a parent. When I went to Thomas and told him I wanted to have Maxie I also knew it was a decision that could have left me a single, young parent and it was  responsibly I was ready to take on. Luckily I had a boyfriend who packed up and moved in with me, only to now be the best daddy!

Being pregnant and being a parent is a conscious that a women should make on her own. Being pregnant comes with so many possible heath risks, not  mention the mental toll it could take on a woman NOT ready to carry a child. I went through a whole pregnancy with chronic vomiting and preeclampsia.  Being a parent is a 24/7 thing on top of what you have to do for yourself, which can be taxing and mentally straining as well.

I love being a mom, but that doesn't mean every woman feels the same, which is 100% okay! Every lady should have the say so over her own body! 

Have a story to share? Click here: http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/submit

status_message:
✔ Pregnant
✔ Parenting
✔ Pro-Choice

My husband and I experienced three painful miscarriages before our son was born. After the third, we visited a counselor. The grief was too much for us to bear on our own. The counselor made a huge mistake during the session. His office was close to a Marie Stopes Clinic. He told us that every morning when he drove to work and thought about all the families dealing with infertility, he wanted to "burn [the Marie Stopes clinic] down." I was shocked and outraged but too emotional with my own grief to manage more than a comment about how his remark was inappropriate. I've thought often since then about what I should have said. My message today is for him. 

I am a mother by choice. I was never certain that I wanted children, but when I met my loving husband, it became clear that parenthood was our path. When it didn't happen easily, we were devastated. I experienced emotional and physical pain, including severe hemorrhaging and emergency hospital visits. Eventually we were fortunate to have the means for and access to IVF. This picture was taken just hours after our son was born. I had an emergency cesarean because I had developed life threatening HELLP syndrome. 

Looking back, I can honestly say that there is not one moment when I would have begrudged another woman the right to choose to end her pregnancy. Some may find that to be a contradiction, but I see it as the most uncomplicated representation of my belief in sexual and reproductive rights. In fact, claiming to be "pro-life" and stating that a Marie Stopes Clinic should be "burned down" is the real contradiction. — Naomi Lince-Deroche http://rhrc.us/1JdNXbg
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
"The day I stood next to my son's birth mother in the operating room for her C-section and together we heard our son cry for the first time was the best day of my life – and it reinforced to me why adoption must be a choice and no one should ever be forced to carry a pregnancy to term. 

My family was created through open adoption. It's no coincidence birth parents gained much more power in adoption after Roe v. Wade legalized abortion in the United States. The work I do is about more than abortion rights, it's about ensuring that every pregnant person is able to make the best decision they can for themselves and their families – whether that is abortion, parenting or making an adoption plan. My experience with infertility, as a foster parent and creating my family through open adoption has only strengthened my resolve to work to ensure that all pregnant people have self-determination and all pregnancy choices are honored and supported." - Nikki Madsen, Executive Director of Abortion Care Network 

#ProChoiceParents  http://rhrc.us/1IO7LBy
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message:
✔ Pregnant
✔ Parenting
✔ Pro-Choice

"I have a 3 year old daughter and I'm currently 31 weeks pregnant. I have been pregnant four times, twice after my daughter. One pregnancy ended in abortion because of a serious medical issue where I nearly bled to death at thirteen weeks. I should not need to almost die to be given access to abortion.

This pregnancy has been difficult and painful and my partner and I have made the very conscious decision to terminate the pregnancy if my health or the fetus' health is at serious risk. Hopefully that doesn't happen and hopefully if it does, I can deliver immediately. I need to think about the baby that is already alive and the man I chose to start my family with; I'm not just an incubator for fetuses.

As an indigenous woman, the historical trauma is ever present. Women were forced to undergo serious surgery to stop them from having children or were raped by white men and bore their children by force. On reservations, women are 25% more likely to be raped and considering the only health provider is Indian Health Services, a federally run facility, good luck getting an abortion.

Becoming a mother has made me more pro choice than ever because it effects family dynamics and finances, everything under the sun so if a woman isn't ready for children, who are we to prevent her from developing as a person first to become a good mother later or supporting her choice to never be a parent? My daughter and hopefully son realize how important it is to support mothers and women; it's not only a part of human rights, it's a huge part of our culture and tradition. Women bear a huge responsibility; why not support half the population??"

http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/post/121616247634/that-is-me-in-the-pink-i-have-a-three-year-old
link_name: Pregnant, Parenting, Pro-Choice

status_message: No bowls of Plan B are required at work. No IUD insertions at your desk. For a woman to get contraception, she has to use her insurance plan—the one belonging to *her*, not her employer—to cover it at a pharmacy.

status_message:
Planned Parenthood legally helps people who wish to donate tissue do so. There are no "profits." 

One, Planned Parenthood does not sell fetal tissue for profit. Rather, labs, companies, and scientists interested in tissue pay the administrative and shipping costs.  Two, people have a right to donate their tissue, organs, and body parts for scientific research and to benefit others.
link_name: Profiting From Fetal Body Parts? The GOP Sure Is

status_message:
Life-changing events that trigger healthcare enrollment eligibility include marriage, divorce, and moving out of state—but not pregnancy itself. This can be corrected without Congress.

HHS has the authority to add pregnancy as one of the qualifying life events that lets people enroll at any time, like getting married, leaving prison, or giving birth.

status_message:
We are very sad to hear of the passing of Dr. Mildred "Millie" Hanson, a trailblazing abortion provider in Minnesota. As an ob/gyn resident in 1959, she saw women dying from illegal abortions—and dedicated her life to ensuring that safe abortion was available. 

Our thoughts are with Dr. Hanson's family and friends. More here, at Physicians for Reproductive Health: http://rhrc.us/1x0Tt6z
